row.title: Terminology Resources
row.field_page_description: NCI's reference terminology and related vocabulary resources to help researchers, clinicians, and administrators identify types of cancer, treatments, and other cancer-related topics.

row.title: FDA Terminology
row.field_page_description: FDA works with NCI EVS to develop regulatory and other controlled terminology standards.
row.field_feature_card_description: FDA works with NCI EVS to develop regulatory and other controlled terminology in several areas. Some 15,000 terms are stored in NCIt.
row.field_list_description: U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) works with NCI EVS to develop regulatory and other controlled terminology in several areas. Some 15,000 terms are stored in NCI Thesaurus (NCIt).
row.meta_keywords: FDA regulatory controlled terminology standards

row.title: CDISC Terminology
row.field_page_description: Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) is an international, non-profit organization that develops and supports global data standards for medical research. CDISC is working actively with EVS to develop and support controlled terminology in several areas, notably CDISC's Study Data Tabulation Model (SDTM).
row.field_feature_card_description: CDISC and NCI EVS partner to develop global terminology and data standards for biomedical research.
row.field_list_description: Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) is an international, non-profit organization that develops and supports global data standards for medical research. CDISC is working actively with EVS to develop and support controlled terminology in several areas, notably CDISC's Study Data Tabulation Model (SDTM).

row.title: NCPDP Terminology
row.field_page_description: NCPDP Terminology developed with NCI EVS for prescription drugs.

row.title: NCI's Clinical Trials Programs and Initiatives
row.field_page_description: Information about NCI programs and initiatives that sponsor, conduct, develop, or support clinical trials, including NCI’s Clinical Trial Network (NCTN) and NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) initiatives.

row.title: Treating Multiply Relapsed or Refractory Hairy Cell Leukemia
row.field_short_title: Treating Multiply Relapsed or Refractory Hairy Cell Leukemia
row.field_page_description: In this trial, patients with hairy cell leukemia who have not responded or relapsed after initial chemotherapy will be randomly assigned to receive rituximab combined with either pentostatin or bendamustine.
row.field_feature_card_description: In this trial, patients with hairy cell leukemia who have not responded or relapsed after initial chemotherapy will be randomly assigned to receive rituximab combined with either pentostatin or bendamustine.
row.field_list_description: In this trial, patients with hairy cell leukemia who have not responded to initial chemotherapy followed by second-line treatment with rituximab, or who have relapsed following two courses of chemotherapy, will be randomly assigned to receive rituximab combined with either pentostatin or bendamustine.
row.field_browser_title: Treating Multiply Relapsed or Refractory Hairy Cell Leukemia
row.field_card_title: Treating Multiply Relapsed or Refractory Hairy Cell Leukemia
row.meta_keywords: hairy cell leukemia, HCL, rituximab, Rituxan, pentostatin, bendamustine, Nipent, Treanda

row.title: Sallie Rosen Kaplan (SRK) Postdoctoral Fellowship for Women Scientists

row.title: Vaccine Reduces HPV Infections in Young Men
row.field_short_title: Vaccine Reduces HPV Infections in Young Men
row.field_page_description: An international randomized clinical trial has shown that the vaccine Gardasil can reduce the incidence of anogenital human papillomavirus (HPV) infections in young men 16 to 26 years of age at the time of vaccination.

row.title: Three-Drug Combination Benefits Some Patients with Relapsed Multiple Myeloma
row.field_short_title: Three-Drug Combination for Relapsed Multiple Myeloma
row.field_page_description: A summary of Interim results from an international, randomized phase III trial that suggest that adding carfilzomib (Kyprolis®) to a standard treatment improves outcomes for patients with multiple myeloma whose cancer has relapsed.
row.field_feature_card_description: Interim results from an international, randomized phase III trial suggest that adding carfilzomib (Kyprolis®) to a standard treatment improves outcomes for patients with multiple myeloma whose cancer has relapsed.
row.field_list_description: Interim results from an international, randomized phase III trial suggest that adding carfilzomib (Kyprolis®) to a standard treatment improves outcomes for patients with multiple myeloma whose cancer has relapsed. Participants in the study who received carfilzomib plus lenalidomide (Revlimid®) and dexamethasone lived a median of 8.7 months longer without the disease getting worse than patients who received lenalidomide and dexamethasone alone.
row.field_browser_title: Three-Drug Combination for Relapsed Multiple Myeloma
row.field_card_title: Three-Drug Combination for Relapsed Multiple Myeloma
row.meta_keywords: carfilzomib, Kyprolis, lenalidomide, Revlimid, dexamethasone, multiple myeloma, Keith Stewart, Mark Roschewski

row.field_page_description: This report provides a yearly update of cancer incidence (new cases) and mortality (death) rates, and trends in these rates in the United States. The special feature section of this year’s report highlights the incidence of breast cancer subtypes by race,
row.field_list_description: This report provides a yearly update of cancer incidence (new cases) and mortality (death) rates, and trends in these rates in the United States. The special feature section of this year’s report highlights the incidence of breast cancer subtypes by race, ethnicity, poverty level and state.

row.title: Cancer Disparities
row.field_page_description: Basic information about cancer disparities in the U.S., factors that contribute to the disproportionate burden of cancer in some groups, and examples of disparities in incidence and mortality among certain populations.
row.field_feature_card_description: Many factors contribute to the fact that minorities and other groups tend to bear an unequal burden of cancer.
row.field_list_description: Certain groups bear an unequal burden of cancer. Learn about the factors that contribute to cancer disparities and find examples of disparities in incidence and mortality among certain populations.

row.title: Breast Cancers Arising Between Mammograms Have Aggressive Features
row.field_short_title: Breast Cancers Between Mammograms Have Aggressive Features
row.field_page_description: Breast cancers that are discovered in the period between regular screening mammograms—known as interval cancers—are more likely to have features associated with aggressive behavior and a poor prognosis than cancers found via screening mammograms.
row.field_list_description: Breast cancers that are discovered in the period between regular screening mammograms—known as interval cancers—are more likely to have features associated with aggressive behavior and a poor prognosis than cancers found via screening mammograms, according to research in the May 3, 2011, issue of the Journal of the National Cancer Institute.

row.title: Preventing High-Risk Adenomas and Second Cancers in Colon Cancer Survivors
row.field_short_title: Preventing High-Risk Adenomas and Second Cancers in Colon Cancer Survivors
row.field_page_description: In this phase III trial, people who have had curative surgery for colon cancer will be randomly assigned to take sulindac and a placebo, eflornithine and a placebo, both sulindac and eflornithine, or two placebo pills for 36 months.
row.field_feature_card_description: In this phase III trial, people who have had curative surgery for colon cancer will be randomly assigned to take sulindac and a placebo, eflornithine and a placebo, both sulindac and eflornithine, or two placebo pills for 36 months.
row.field_list_description: In this phase III trial, people who have undergone curative surgery for stage 0-3 colon cancer, with or without adjuvant chemotherapy, will be randomly assigned to take sulindac and a placebo, eflornithine and a placebo, both sulindac and eflornithine, or two placebo pills for 36 months.

row.title: Radium-223 Improves Survival in Patients with Advanced Prostate Cancer
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a phase III trial that compared radium-223 dichloride plus the best standard of care versus a placebo plus the best standard of care in men with metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Results from a phase III trial show that radium-223 dichloride (Xofigo®) improves overall survival in men with advanced prostate cancer that has spread to their bones compared with placebo.
row.field_list_description: Results from a phase III trial show that radium-223 dichloride (Xofigo®) improves overall survival in men with advanced prostate cancer that has spread to their bones compared with placebo.

row.title: Finasteride Reduces the Risk of Low-Grade Prostate Cancer in Men 55 and Older
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a phase III trial that tested whether the drug finasteride could help prevent prostate cancer in men age 55 and older.
row.field_feature_card_description: Long-term follow-up results from a phase III trial show that regular use of finasteride (Proscar®) for up to 7 years decreased the risk of low-grade prostate cancer in men age 55 and older compared with that in men who received a placebo. Although high-gr
row.field_list_description: Long-term follow-up results from a phase III trial show that regular use of finasteride (Proscar®) for up to 7 years decreased the risk of low-grade prostate cancer in men age 55 and older compared with that in men who received a placebo. Although high-grade cancers were more common in the finasteride group, the finasteride and placebo groups had similar 15-year overall survival rates.
row.meta_keywords: finasteride, Proscar, prostate cancer, PCPT, Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial, Ian Thompson

row.title: Harnessing the Power of Our Immune Systems to Treat Neuroblastoma: Discovery of Ch14.18 Immunotherapy
row.field_page_description: Neuroblastoma is rare yet it's the most common cancer affecting infants. Prior to a discovery 20 years in the making, there was little hope for survival in children with advanced stages of the disease. Today, research is leading to a brighter outlook.
row.field_list_description: Neuroblastoma is rare yet it's the most common cancer affecting infants. Prior to a discovery 20 years in the making, there was little hope for survival in children with advanced stages of the disease. Today, research is leading to a brighter outlook.
row.field_browser_title: Discovery – Ch14.18 Immunotherapy to Treat Neuroblastoma

row.title: Pomalidomide plus Low-Dose Dexamethasone Improves Survival for Patients with Multiple Myeloma
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a phase III trial that compared the combination of pomalidomide (Pomalyst®) and low-dose dexamethasone versus high-dose dexamethasone alone in patients with multiple myeloma that has progressed despite other treatments.
row.field_feature_card_description: Results from a randomized phase III trial show that the combination of pomalidomide (Pomalyst®) and low-dose dexamethasone may benefit some patients with multiple myeloma that has progressed despite other treatments.
row.field_list_description: Results from a randomized phase III trial show that the combination of pomalidomide (Pomalyst®) and low-dose dexamethasone may benefit some patients with multiple myeloma that has progressed (worsened) despite other treatments. Patients who received the combination therapy lived longer without the disease getting worse than patients who received high-dose dexamethasone alone. Overall survival was also improved in the group that received the combination therapy compared with the other group.
row.meta_keywords: pomalidomide, Pomalyst, dexamethasone, multiple myeloma, Jesus San Miguel

row.title: Targeted Agents Active Against HER2-positive Breast Cancer: Questions and Answers
row.field_short_title: Targeted Agents Active Against Breast Cancer: Q&A
row.field_page_description: ALTTO was a clinical trial designed to determine whether the combination of the monoclonal antibody trastuzumab (Herceptin) and the drug lapatinib (Tykerb) was more effective in treating HER2/ErbB2-positive breast cancer when combined with chemotherapy than either agent alone. Results from ALTTO did not show additional benefit from combining lapatinib and trastuzumab compared with trastuzumab treatment alone.
row.field_feature_card_description: ALTTO was a clinical trial designed to determine whether the combination of the monoclonal antibody trastuzumab (Herceptin) and the drug lapatinib (Tykerb) was more effective in treating HER2/ErbB2-positive breast cancer when combined with chemotherapy.

Results from ALTTO did not show additional benefit from combining lapatinib and trastuzumab compared with trastuzumab treatment alone.

row.title: Rituximab Retreatment after Disease Progression Is Comparable to Rituximab Maintenance Therapy in Patients with Low-Tumor Burden Follicular Lymphoma
row.field_short_title: Rituximab Retreatment for Low-Tumor Burden Follicular Lymphoma
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a randomized clinical trial of patients with low–tumor burden follicular lymphoma that compared maintenance therapy with rituximab versus retreatment with rituximab only when there was evidence of disease progression.
row.field_feature_card_description: In a randomized clinical trial, patients with low–tumor burden follicular lymphoma who responded to initial treatment with rituximab experienced similar disease control whether they received rituximab maintenance therapy or were retreated with rituximab.
row.field_list_description: In a randomized clinical trial, patients with low–tumor burden follicular lymphoma whose cancer responded to initial treatment with rituximab (Rituxan®) experienced similar disease control regardless of whether they subsequently received maintenance therapy with rituximab or were retreated with rituximab only when there was evidence of disease progression.
row.field_browser_title: Rituximab Retreatment for Low-Tumor Burden Follicular Lymphoma
row.field_card_title: Rituximab Retreatment for Low-Tumor Burden Follicular Lymphoma
row.meta_keywords: rituximab, Rituxan, follicular lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, NHL, retreatment, low–tumor burden, Brad Kahl, Mark Roschewski

row.title: Advance Directives
row.field_page_description: Advance directives are legal documents that allow you to decide ahead of time what kind of medical care you want or who you want to make decisions for you if you're too ill to speak for yourself.
row.field_feature_card_description: Advance directives are legal documents that allow you to decide ahead of time how you want to be treated.
row.field_list_description: Advance directives are legal documents that allow you to decide ahead of time what kind of medical care you want or who you want to make decisions for you if you're too ill to speak for yourself.

row.title: Using Trusted Resources
row.field_page_description: Information to help people evaluate the source and credibility of health information that they find in print or online.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information to help people evaluate the source and credibility of health information that they find in print or online.
row.field_list_description: Some online sources can provide misleading or incorrect information. Health information, whether in print or online, should come from a trusted, credible source

row.title: How Cancer Is Diagnosed
row.field_page_description: Learn about tests and procedures that diagnose cancer. Your doctor may ask about personal and family medical history or order lab tests, imaging scans, or a biopsy.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn about tests and procedures that doctors might order to diagnose cancer.
row.field_list_description: If you have a symptom that does not go away or a screening test result that suggests cancer, the doctor must find out whether it is due to cancer or some other cause. Learn about tests and procedures that help figure out the reason for your problems.

row.title: Constipation and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Cancer treatment can cause constipation. Symptoms include hard stools, stomach cramps, bloating, and nausea. Causes also include pain medicine, diet changes, dehydration, and being less active. Prevention and treatment of constipation is explained.
row.field_list_description: What causes constipation in people with cancer? Constipation is a side effect of cancer treatments. Learn about symptoms, causes, prevention, and treatment of constipation.
row.meta_keywords: constipation, hard stools, symptoms, stomach cramps, bloating, nausea, prevention, treatment

row.title: Nerve Problems (Peripheral Neuropathy) and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Nerve problems, such as peripheral neuropathy, can be caused by cancer treatment. Learn about signs and symptoms of nerve changes. Find out how to prevent or manage nerve problems during cancer treatment.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes nerve problems, a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to prevent or manage it.
row.meta_keywords: peripheral neuropathy

row.title: Skin and Nail Changes during Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Cancer treatments can cause skin to become dry, itchy, red, or peel. Nails may become dark, yellow, or cracked. Learn about signs of skin problems that may need urgent medical care. Get a helpful list of questions to ask your doctor.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes skin and nail changes, a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to prevent or manage them.
row.field_browser_title: Side Effects: Skin and Nail Changes
row.meta_keywords: skin changes, nail changes, pruritus, immunotherapy, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, sores, skin products

row.title: Diarrhea and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Diarrhea, a side effect of cancer treatment, may cause symptoms such as loose, watery stools. Diarrhea can lead to dehydration and malnutrition in cancer patients. Learn about ways to treat and manage diarrhea during cancer treatment.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes diarrhea, a side effect of cancer treatment, and ways to manage it. Symptoms and treatments to manage diarrhea are also explained for cancer patients.
row.meta_keywords: Diarrhea, loose stools, symptoms, dehydration, malnutrition, treatment, prevention, cancer patient

row.title: Pain in People with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Controlling pain is an important part of your cancer treatment plan. Learn how to track levels of pain. Find out how pain, a side effect of cancer treatment, is treated using acupuncture, biofeedback, and physical therapy.
row.field_list_description: What causes pain? How can I treat or lessen pain during cancer treatment? Pain is a side effect of some cancer treatments. Learn how to prevent pain, treat pain, or lessen pain in cancer patients. Get a list of questions to ask your doctor about pain.

row.title: Urinary and Bladder Problems
row.field_page_description: Problems such as radiation cystitis and urinary tract infections, which are sometimes caused by cancer treatments, are discussed along with ways to prevent or manage them.
row.field_list_description: Information about the causes and symptoms of urinary and bladder problems, a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to prevent or manage them.
row.field_browser_title: Side Effects: Urinary and Bladder Problems

row.title: Edema (Swelling) and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Edema is a condition in which fluid builds up in your body’s tissues. The swelling may be caused by chemotherapy, cancer, and conditions not related to cancer. Learn about signs of edema, including swelling in your feet, ankles, and legs.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes edema, a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to prevent or lessen it.
row.meta_keywords: edema, swelling, cancer treatment side effect, signs, prevention

row.title: Hair Loss (Alopecia) and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Hair loss, also called alopecia, is a side effect of cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Learn how to cope with and manage hair loss. Listen to tips from others who have experienced hair loss.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes hair loss (also called alopecia), a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to manage before and after hair loss.
row.meta_keywords: hair loss, alopecia, side effect, cancer treatment, coping, support

row.title: Infection and Neutropenia during Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Infection and neutropenia can be serious side effects during cancer treatment. Chemotherapy can increase your risk. Learn how to prevent infection during treatment. Find out what signs and symptoms to call the doctor about.
row.field_list_description: Information about what cancer treatments increase the risks of infection and neutropenia, the signs of infection, and ways to prevent it.
row.meta_keywords: infection, neutropenia, side effect cancer treatment, signs, symptoms, prevention

row.title: Lymphedema and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Lymphedema is a side effect of some cancer treatments. Symptoms of lymphedema are presented. Ways to treat or manage swelling in the arm or leg are covered for cancer patients and cancer survivors.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes lymphedema, a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to manage or treat it.
row.meta_keywords: lymphedema, cancer treatment, symptoms, management

row.title: Memory or Concentration Problems and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Cancer treatments, such as chemo, may cause difficulty thinking, concentrating, or other cognitive problems. Learn about steps people with cancer can take to manage these side effects. See a list of helpful questions for families to ask the doctor.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes memory or concentration problems, a side effect of some cancer treatments, and ways to manage it.
row.field_browser_title: Side Effects - Memory or Concentration Problems
row.meta_keywords: memory problems, concentration, cognitive problems, side effect, cancer treatment

row.title: Symptoms of Cancer
row.field_page_description: Cancer can cause different symptoms, such as abnormal bumps, night sweats, or unexplained weight gain or loss. Only a doctor can tell if symptoms are caused by cancer or some other problem.
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer has many different symptoms. Only a doctor can tell if your symptoms are caused by cancer.
row.field_list_description: Cancer can cause different symptoms, such as abnormal bumps, night sweats, or unexplained weight gain or loss. Only a doctor can tell if symptoms are caused by cancer or some other problem.

row.title: Screening Tests
row.field_page_description: Information about tests such as mammography and colonoscopy that may be used to screen for cancer in people without symptoms of disease.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about cancer screening and the types of tests used to find cancer.
row.field_list_description: Information about tests that may be used to screen for cancer in people without symptoms of disease.

row.title: NCI’s Role in Cancer Research
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI supports and advances cancer research in many ways.

row.title: Cancer Staging
row.field_page_description: Staging is the process of determining how much cancer is within the body (tumor size) and if it has spread. Learn about the TNM Staging system and other ways that stage is described.
row.field_feature_card_description: Stage describes details about your cancer, such as tumor size and if it has spread. Staging guides decisions about treatment.
row.field_list_description: Staging is the process of determining details about your cancer, such as tumor size and if it has spread. The stage guides decisions about treatment.

row.title: Spotlight on Scientists Videos
row.field_page_description: Researchers, fellows, principal investigators, and medical doctors provide inspiration and advice to students interested in medical research.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI-supported scientists explain key aspects of basic and clinical cancer research; describe how and why they became cancer researchers, with advice for students; and offer their perspectives on a range of challenges and achievements in cancer research.
row.field_list_description: NCI scientists, from postdoctoral fellows to principal investigators, discuss various topics including their personal backgrounds, how they came to be in the field of cancer research, their current projects, and a look to the future of medical oncology.
row.meta_keywords: Scientist, oncology, molecular biologist, postdoctoral fellow, medical doctor, graduate school, career, science, post doc, National Cancer Institute, NCI, National Institutes of Health, NIH, Spotlight on Scientists

row.title: Reports
row.field_page_description: Information about major NCI reports as well as other reports released by government health agencies and nonprofit groups that provide information about cancer.

row.title: Delirium and Cancer Treatment
row.field_short_title: Diagnosing and Treating Delirium in Cancer Patients
row.field_page_description: Delirium is a confused mental state. Symptoms may include changes in thinking and sleeping. In cancer patients, it may be caused by medicine, dehydration, or happen at the end of life. Delirium may be mistaken for depression or dementia.
row.field_list_description: Delirium during cancer treatment is explained, including what causes it and how it is treated. Hypoactive delirium, hyperactive delirium, and mixed delirium are explained. Questions to ask your family member's doctor are also included.
row.field_card_title: Diagnosing and Treating Delirium in Cancer Patients
row.meta_keywords: delirium, hypoactive delirium, hyperactive delirium, mixed delirium, side effect

row.title: Vaccine Therapy for Unresectable Chordoma
row.field_page_description: In this phase II clinical trial, adult patients with inoperable chordoma who are scheduled to undergo radiation therapy will be randomly assigned to receive a yeast-based vaccine that targets a protein called brachyury or a placebo injection.
row.field_feature_card_description: In this phase II clinical trial, adult patients with unresectable localized chordoma who are scheduled to undergo radiation therapy will be randomly assigned to receive the yeast-brachyury vaccine or a placebo injection.
row.field_list_description: In this phase II clinical trial, adult patients with inoperable chordoma, a type of bone cancer, who are scheduled to undergo radiation therapy will be randomly assigned to receive a yeast-based vaccine that targets a protein called brachyury or a placebo injection.
row.meta_keywords: vaccine, chordoma, immunotherapy

row.title: New Therapies Are Changing the Outlook for Advanced Melanoma
row.field_short_title: New Therapies Available for Advanced Melanoma
row.field_page_description: An article about a host of new treatment options that have been produced in the last several years for patients with the skin cancer melanoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: n the last several years, after decades of little progress, a host of new treatment options have been produced for patients with the skin cancer melanoma. And the progress is showing no signs of slowing.
row.field_list_description: In the last several years, after decades of little progress, a host of new treatment options have been produced for patients with the skin cancer melanoma. Since 2011, the FDA has approved seven new treatments for advanced melanoma that has spread to other parts of the body. And the progress is showing no signs of slowing.
row.field_browser_title: New Therapies Available for Advanced Melanoma
row.field_card_title: New Therapies Available for Advanced Melanoma
row.meta_keywords: immunotherapy, melanoma, targeted therapy, checkpoint inhibitor, PD-1, CTLA-4, skin cancer, BRAF, MEK, vemurafenib, dabrafenib, trametinib, ipilimumab, pembrolizumab

row.field_page_description: Learn how these investigators' projects aim to break new ground in biomedical, behavioral, and clinical cancer research.

row.title: Thinking Chemically to Discover New Targeted Cancer Drugs
row.field_short_title: Thinking Chemically to Discover New Targeted Cancer Drugs-Kevan Shokat, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: About a third of all cancers are driven by mutations in RAS genes. Learn how NCI funding is helping Dr. Kevan Shokat develop drugs that inactivate molecular drivers of cancer such as RAS.
row.field_feature_card_description: Chemical biologist Kevan Shokat, Ph.D., uses his unique perspective to develop molecularly targeted therapies.

row.field_card_title: Thinking Chemically to Discover New Targeted Cancer Drugs

row.title: Shining a Spotlight on Tumor Exosomes
row.field_short_title: Shining a Spotlight on Tumor Exosomes-David Lyden M.D., Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: Learn how NCI support is helping researcher David Lyden understand how cancer cell exosomes create a nurturing environment for the growth of metastatic tumors.
row.field_feature_card_description: Pediatric neuro-oncologist David Lyden, M.D., Ph.D., studies exosomes to uncover the steps of cancer cell metastasis.
row.field_card_title: Shining a Spotlight on Tumor Exosomes

row.title: Pursuing a Cancer Prevention Vaccine
row.field_short_title: Pursuing a Cancer Prevention Vaccine-Olivera Finn, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: Read the story of NCI-funded scientist Olivera Finn whose research led to the first clinical trial of a prevention vaccine for people at high risk for cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Olivera Finn, Ph.D., has pursued this goal since her research team discovered the first tumor antigen.

row.title: Using Tandem Transplants to Treat Neuroblastoma
row.field_short_title: Using Tandem Transplants to Treat Neuroblastoma-Julie Park, M.D.
row.field_page_description: Learn how an NCI-supported trial led by Julie Park established a new standard of care for children with high-risk neuroblastoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: Julie Park, M.D., led a trial that changed the way neuroblastoma is treated in the US.
row.field_browser_title: Using Tandem Transplants to Treat Neuroblastoma
row.field_card_title: Using Tandem Transplants to Treat Neuroblastoma

row.title: Searching for Less-Toxic Cancer Treatments for Kids
row.field_short_title: Searching for Less-Toxic Cancer Treatments for Kids-Gregory Aune, M.D., Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: Frustration with the toxicities of chemotherapy and radiation spurs cancer survivor and investigator Greg Aune to look for less-toxic therapies for children.
row.field_feature_card_description: Gregory Aune, M.D., Ph.D., focuses on identifying biomarkers of toxicity caused by powerful cancer drugs.
row.field_browser_title: Searching for Less-Toxic Cancer Treatments for Kids
row.field_card_title: Searching for Less-Toxic Cancer Treatments for Kids

row.title: Running (and Eating) Away from Cancer
row.field_short_title: Running (and Eating) Away from Cancer-Sue Wharfe
row.field_page_description: Learn how Sue Wharfe benefitted from taking part in a clinical trial of exercise and nutrition for breast cancer survivors that was supported by NCI funding.
row.field_feature_card_description: Is obesity associated with worse survival for patients with breast cancer? Sue Wharfe participated in a study to address this question.

row.title: Working to Reduce the Cancer Burden Caused by Tobacco
row.field_short_title: Working to Reduce the Cancer Burden Caused by Tobacco-Michael Fiore, M.D., M.P.H., M.B.A.
row.field_page_description: Tobacco use in the US continues to cause great harm. Learn about Dr. Michael Fiore and his NCI working group’s recommendations on Tobacco Control Research Priorities for the Next Decade.
row.field_feature_card_description: Michael Fiore, M.D., M.P.H., M.B.A., helped to spearhead an NCI working group that recommended tobacco research priorities.
row.field_browser_title: Reducing the Cancer Burden Caused by Tobacco
row.field_card_title: Reducing the Cancer Burden Caused by Tobacco

row.title: Addressing Cancer Disparities in Appalachia
row.field_short_title: Addressing Cancer Disparities in Appalachia-Electra Paskett, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: Dr. Electra Paskett addresses cancer disparities through science and community partnerships. With NCI’s support, her efforts have made improvements in underserved communities.
row.field_feature_card_description: Electra Paskett, Ph.D., has devoted her career to addressing cancer disparities in the United States.

row.title: HPV and Cancer
row.field_page_description: Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are a group of more than 200 related viruses that can cause several cancers including cervical cancer, anal cancer, and oropharyngeal cancer. Learn more about how HPV is transmitted, the different types of HPV, and vaccines to prevent HPV.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn about the link between human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and cancer.
row.field_list_description: Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are a group of more than 200 related viruses that can cause several cancers including cervical cancer, anal cancer, and oropharyngeal cancer. Learn more about how HPV is transmitted, the different types of HPV, and vaccines to prevent HPV.

row.title: NCI Director’s Innovation Award Past Recipients
row.field_page_description: Director’s Innovation Award Program list of past recipients from the Center for Cancer Research.
row.field_list_description: The NCI Director’s Innovation Award Program is designed to support development of highly innovative approaches and technology aimed at significant cancer-related problems. Proposals with the potential for high impact, the potential to generate new intellectual property or technology, or which are considered too high-risk or preliminary to pursue within the base budget allocation or emphasis on health disparities are encouraged.

row.title: TARGET Initiative Leading the Way to New and Exciting Discoveries in Childhood Cancers
row.field_page_description: Tapping into collaborative science: NCI's TARGET initiative makes discoveries in childhood cancers possible, such as genetic tests to address blood cancer

row.title: Aspirin to Reduce Cancer Risk
row.field_page_description: A federal advisory panel supports aspirin to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, while researchers are investigating whether it may help reduce the risk of other cancers.
row.field_feature_card_description: Aspirin may reduce colorectal cancer risk, but what about other cancers?
row.field_list_description: Even as a federal advisory panel has supported the use of aspirin to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer in some people, researchers are investigating how aspirin works against cancer and whether it may help reduce the risk of other cancers.
row.field_card_title: Aspirin May Help to Reduce Cancer Risk

row.title: Velcade®: A New Tool in the Fight against Multiple Myeloma
row.field_short_title: Velcade® and the Fight against Multiple Myeloma
row.field_page_description: Velcade® represents a new type of anticancer drug called proteasome inhibitors. It has shown promise in the treatment of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the white blood cells. Velcade® is being studied for use in a variety of blood cancers and solid tumors.
row.field_list_description: Velcade® represents a new type of anticancer drug called proteasome inhibitors. It has shown promise in the treatment of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the white blood cells. Velcade® is being studied for use in a variety of blood cancers and solid tumors.

row.field_card_title: Velcade® and the Fight against Multiple Myeloma
row.meta_keywords: cancer research, multiple myeloma, Velcade, bortezomib, cancer treatment

row.title: Lung Cancer Screening Saves Lives: The National Lung Screening Trial
row.field_page_description: NCI funded the National Lung Screening Trial, an eight-year study that used new technology to detect small, aggressive tumors early enough to surgically remove them. This approach reduced lung cancer deaths among participants by 20 percent.
row.field_list_description: NCI funded the National Lung Screening Trial, an eight-year study that used new technology to detect small, aggressive tumors early enough to surgically remove them. This approach reduced lung cancer deaths among participants by 20 percent.
row.field_browser_title: Discovery – Lung Cancer Screening Saves Lives: The NLST
row.meta_keywords: cancer research, lung cancer, screening, computed tomography, helical CT, National Lung Screening Trial, NLST

row.title: CGH Future Directions
row.field_page_description: Looking ahead, the Center for Global Health has three major future directions that will help to achieve NCI’s goal of advancing global cancer research, building expertise, and leveraging resources across nations to address the challenges of cancer and reduce cancer deaths worldwide.
row.field_feature_card_description: As cancer diseases and research continue to evolve, we too will move forward with stronger, more collaborative work.

row.title: What We Do
row.field_page_description: To advance global cancer research, build expertise, improve cancer prevention and cancer screening in low to middle income countries (LMICs), and reduce cancer deaths worldwide, CGH facilitates research efforts through collaboration with U.S. government agencies, foreign governments, non-government organizations, and pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.

row.title: Treatment Prevents Chemotherapy Side Effects for Children with Cancer
row.field_short_title: Treatment Prevents Chemotherapy Side Effects for Children with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Adding aprepitant to the anti-nausea drug ondansetron, with or without dexamethasone, effectively prevents chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in children.
row.field_feature_card_description: Adding aprepitant to the anti-nausea drug ondansetron, with or without dexamethasone, effectively prevents chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in children.
row.field_list_description: Final results from a phase III randomized clinical trial show that addition of aprepitant to the anti-nausea drug ondansetron, with or without dexamethasone, effectively prevents chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in pediatric patients.
row.field_browser_title: Treatment Prevents Chemotherapy Side Effects for Children with Cancer
row.field_card_title: Treatment Prevents Chemo Side Effects in Children

row.title: NCI and the Precision Medicine Initiative®
row.field_short_title: NCI and the Precision Medicine Initiative®
row.field_page_description: NCI's activities related to precision medicine focuses on new and expanded precision medicine clinical trials; mechanisms to overcome drug resistance to cancer treatments; and developing a shared digital repository of precision medicine trials data.
row.field_feature_card_description: To improve patient outcomes, NCI is accelerating research on the molecular abnormalities that drive cancer.
row.field_list_description: Under this initiative, NCI is focusing on four broad areas: new and expanded precision medicine clinical trials; overcoming drug resistance to cancer treatments; developing new laboratory models for cancer research; and building and sharing a digital repository of data resulting from NCI-sponsored precision medicine clinical trials, all with the aim of bringing precision medicine into everyday clinical practice.
row.field_browser_title: NCI and the Precision Medicine Initiative®
row.field_card_title: NCI and the Precision Medicine Initiative®

row.title: Pembrolizumab Improves Overall Survival in Patients with Advanced Melanoma
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a randomized phase III study that showed pembrolizumab (Keytruda®) improved survival in patients with advanced melanoma compared with Ipilimumab (Yervoy®).
row.field_feature_card_description: Pembrolizumab (Keytruda®) improves survival in patients with advanced melanoma compared with Ipilimumab (Yervoy®).
row.field_list_description: In a randomized phase III study, pembrolizumab (Keytruda®) improved survival in patients with advanced melanoma compared with Ipilimumab (Yervoy®).
row.meta_keywords: pembrolizumab, keytruda, melanoma, keynote 006, pd-1, antoni ribas, howard streicher

row.title: NCI-COG Pediatric MATCH
row.field_page_description: In this precision medicine clinical trial, children and adolescents with advanced cancers whose tumors have certain genetic mutations will be treated with drugs that are matched to those mutations.
row.field_feature_card_description: This trial is studying treatments targeted to tumor alterations in children and adolescents with advanced cancer.
row.field_list_description: In this precision medicine clinical trial, children and adolescents with advanced cancers whose tumors have particular genetic mutations are being treated with drugs designed to target those mutations.

row.title: TAILORx Trial Shows Women at Low Risk for Breast Cancer Recurrence May Forgo Chemotherapy
row.field_short_title: TAILORx Trial Shows Women at Low Risk for Breast Cancer Recurring May Forgo Chemo
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from the Trial Assigning Individualized Options for Treatment, or TAILORx, finds that women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer have a low risk of recurrence based on a test for the expression of 21 genes.
row.field_feature_card_description: The TAILORx trial finds that a molecular test associated with breast cancer recurrence can predict who may benefit from chemotherapy.
row.field_list_description: Initial findings from the Trial Assigning Individualized Options for Treatment, or TAILORx, finds that women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer have a low risk of recurrence based on a test for the expression of 21 genes.

row.title: David Q. Matus, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: David Matus studies cellular invasion--a characteristic behavior of metastatic cancer cells--in an evolutionary context.
row.field_feature_card_description: The Stony Brook University evolutionary developmental biologist studies cellular invasion, a characteristic behavior of metastatic cancer cells.
row.field_list_description: David Matus studies cellular invasion during normal development in the worm, C. elegans, as a model for understanding this behavior in metastatic cancer cells.

row.title: Hormone Replacement Therapy May Improve Survival for Women with Ovarian Cancer
row.field_short_title: Hormone Replacement Therapy May Improve Survival for Women with Ovarian Cancer
row.field_page_description: The randomized, controlled Adjuvant Hormone Therapy trial was launched in 1990 to assess the effects of estrogen-alone hormone replacement therapy in women treated for epithelial ovarian cancer.

row.field_list_description: Study suggests that the use of estrogen-alone hormone replacement therapy may improve overall survival of women treated for epithelial ovarian cancer.

row.title: Fertility Issues in Girls and Women with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Fertility issues are common in women getting cancer treatment. Fertility preservation options include egg freezing, embryo freezing, ovarian tissue freezing, ovarian shielding and ovarian transposition. Resources, support, and clinical trials are listed.
row.field_feature_card_description: It’s important to learn how the recommended cancer treatment may affect fertility before starting treatment.
row.field_list_description: Fertility issues are common in girls and women receiving cancer treatment. Information about fertility preservation options, support, and clinical trials is listed.
row.field_card_title: Fertility Issues in Girls and Women with Cancer

row.title: Fertility Issues in Boys and Men with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Fertility issues are common in boys and men getting cancer treatment. Fertility preservation options include sperm banking, testicular shielding, testicular sperm extraction (TESE), and testicular tissue freezing. Support and clinical trials are listed.
row.field_feature_card_description: Fertility issues are common in boys and men being treated for cancer.
row.field_list_description: Fertility issues are common in boys and men receiving cancer treatment. Information about fertility preservation options, support, and clinical trials is listed.

row.title: Sexual Health Issues in Women with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Cancer treatments such as chemotherapy, hormone therapy, and radiation may cause sexual problems in women. Conditions may include vaginal dryness, vaginal stenosis, and vaginal atrophy. Learn how to manage and treat these sexual problems.
row.field_feature_card_description: Sexual health issues are common in women being treated for cancer.
row.field_list_description: Sexual health issues and changes in a woman’s sex life are common during treatment for cancer. Learn about factors that determine whether a woman’s sexual health is affected and ways to manage changes during treatment for cancer.

row.title: Sexual Health Issues in Men with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Cancer treatments such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy and prostate surgery may affect a man’s sexual function, lower libido, and make it difficult to get an erection. Learn how to manage and treat these sexual problems, during cancer treatment.
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer treatment may have side effects that affect a man's sexual life, but there are ways to manage.
row.field_list_description: Men receiving cancer treatment may have side effects that affect their sexual life. Learn about factors that determine whether sexual health is affected and ways to manage changes during treatment for cancer.
row.field_card_title: Sexual Health Issues in Men with Cancer

row.title: Engineering Personalized Micro-Tumor Ecosystems

row.title: Advances in Breast Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: This page highlights recent research in the detection and treatment of breast cancer. New methods to detect breast cancer, such as 3-D mammography, are described. Treatments tailored to breast cancer subtypes are discussed, including targeted therapies.
row.field_feature_card_description: Clinical advances, research findings, and NCI programs that are leading to progress in finding and treating breast cancer.

row.title: Advances in Pancreatic Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Find highlights of promising research about the treatment of pancreatic cancer, including studies of stroma modifying drugs and immunotherapy combinations. Selected NCI-supported programs that address pancreatic cancer are also described.
row.field_feature_card_description: Clinical advances, research findings, and NCI programs that are leading to progress in treating pancreatic cancer.

row.title: The Finding Cancer Trials Collaborative
row.field_feature_card_description: Let's collaborate! NCI wants to hear from data experts, patient advocates, and others about how our clinical trial data might serve you better.

row.title: Access to Experimental Cancer Drugs
row.field_page_description: An experimental drug has been tested in the lab and with animals and approved for testing in people by the FDA, but can’t yet be advertised, sold, or prescribed. Experimental drugs may be available through clinical trials or expanded access programs - learn more about these programs and how to talk to your doctor.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn how you might gain access to drugs that have been approved for testing in people but can't yet be advertised, sold, or prescribed.
row.field_list_description: An experimental drug is one that has been tested in the lab and with animals and approved for testing in people by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), but can’t yet be advertised, sold, or prescribed. Experimental drugs may be available through clinical trials or expanded access programs.

row.title: Treating KSHV-Associated Multicentric Castleman Disease
row.field_page_description: In this study, patients with KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman disease will receive IV tocilizumab every other week for up to 12 weeks. Patients who do not benefit may go on to receive high-dose AZT and valganciclovir as well.
row.field_feature_card_description: In this study, patients with KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman disease will receive IV tocilizumab every other week for up to 12 weeks. Patients who do not benefit may go on to receive high-dose AZT and valganciclovir as well.
row.field_list_description: In this pilot study, patients with KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman disease will receive intravenous tocilizumab every other week for up to 12 weeks. Patients who do not benefit from tocilizumab therapy alone may go on to receive high-dose AZT and valganciclovir in addition to tocilizumab.
row.meta_keywords: AIDS, HIV, KSHV, AZT, zidovudine, valganciclovir, Castleman, MCD, Acterma

row.intro: A cancer diagnosis is upsetting at any age, but especially so when the patient is a child. It's natural to have many questions, such as, Who should treat my child? Will my child get well? What does all of this mean for our family? Not all questions have answers, but the information and resources on this page provide a starting point for understanding the basics of childhood cancer.

row.title: TAS-102 Improves Overall Survival in Patients with Metastatic Colorectal Cancer
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from an international phase III trial that compared TAS-102 with placebo in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer whose disease progressed following prior treatment.
row.field_feature_card_description: The drug extended the lives of patients whose disease had progressed following standard therapy.
row.field_list_description: In an international randomized phase III trial, the investigational drug TAS-102 extended the lives of patients with metastatic colorectal cancer whose disease had progressed following standard therapies.

row.title: Nivolumab Improves Survival for Some Patients with Advanced Melanoma
row.field_short_title: Nivolumab Improves Survival for Some Patients with Advanced Melanoma
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from an international, double-blind, randomized phase III trial testing the combination of nivolumab (Opdivo®) and ipilimumab (Yervoy®) against nivolumab alone and ipilimumab alone in patients with advanced melanoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab improves progression-free survival for some patients with advanced melanoma.
row.field_list_description: In an international, double-blind, randomized phase III trial, the combination of nivolumab and ipilimumab improved progression-free survival compared with ipilimumab alone for patients with advanced melanoma.

row.title: TMIST (Tomosynthesis Mammographic Imaging Screening Trial)
row.field_page_description: TMIST is a randomized breast screening trial that compares two Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved types of digital mammography, standard digital mammography (2-D) with a newer technology called tomosynthesis mammography (3-D).

row.title: Tumor DNA Sequencing in Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Tumor DNA sequencing (also called genetic profiling or genetic testing) is a test to identify DNA changes in a patient’s cancer. In some cases, this information can help determine a treatment plan.

row.title: Adding Immune-based Treatments to Standard Glioblastoma Therapy
row.field_short_title: Adding Immunotherapy and Vaccine to Standard Glioblastoma Therapy
row.field_page_description: This clinical trial is testing standard therapy (surgery, radiation and temozolomide) plus immunotherapy with pembrolizumab with or without a cancer treatment vaccine for patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma, a common and deadly type of brain tumor.
row.field_feature_card_description: This clinical trial is testing immunotherapy and vaccine therapy for glioblastoma patients.
row.field_list_description: This phase 2 trial is testing standard therapy (surgery, radiation, and temozolomide) plus the checkpoint inhibitor pembrolizumab with or without a cancer treatment vaccine for patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma, a common and deadly type of brain tumor.

row.title: Cancer Screening

row.title: Combination of Nab-Paclitaxel and Gemcitabine Improves Survival in Patients with Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
row.field_short_title: Nab-Paclitaxel Plus Gemcitabine for Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a phase III trial that compared the combination of albumin-bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel [Abraxane®]) and gemcitabine (Gemzar®) versus gemcitabine alone in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: In an international randomized phase III trial, patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer who were treated with a combination of albumin-bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel [Abraxane®]) and gemcitabine (Gemzar®) lived longer than patients who were treated w
row.field_list_description: In an international randomized phase III trial, patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer who were treated with a combination of albumin-bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel [Abraxane®]) and gemcitabine (Gemzar®) lived longer than patients who were treated with gemcitabine alone. Patients who received both drugs also lived longer without their disease getting worse (progression-free survival).
row.field_browser_title: Nab-Paclitaxel Plus Gemcitabine for Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
row.field_card_title: Nab-Paclitaxel Plus Gemcitabine for Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
row.meta_keywords: pancreatic cancer, nab-paclitaxel, gemcitabine, Abraxane, Gemzar, Daniel Von Hoff

row.title: CAR T Cells: Engineering Patients’ Immune Cells to Treat Their Cancers
row.field_short_title: CAR T Cells: Engineering Immune Cells to Treat Cancer
row.field_page_description: Research on CAR T-cell therapy—a rapidly emerging form of cancer treatment, primarily for blood cancers like leukemia and lymphoma—is moving at a swift pace.

row.title: Preventing Stomach Cancer: The Link to H. pylori Bacteria
row.field_short_title: The Link to H. pylori Bacteria
row.field_page_description: NCI supported research to solidify the link between H. pylori infections and stomach cancer. As a result, new cancer treatment and prevention strategies are being developed, encouraging scientists to carefully examine other cancers for viral and bacterial connections.

row.field_card_title: The Link to H. pylori Bacteria

row.title: Using the Immune System in the Fight Against Cancer: Discovery of Rituximab
row.field_page_description: NCI funded the development of rituximab, one of the first monoclonal antibody cancer treatments. With the discovery of rituximab, more than 70 percent of patients diagnosed with non-hodgkin lymphoma now live five years past their initial diagnosis.
row.field_list_description: NCI funded the development of rituximab, one of the first monoclonal antibody cancer treatments. With the discovery of rituximab, more than 70 percent of patients diagnosed with non-hodgkin lymphoma now live five years past their initial diagnosis.
row.meta_keywords: basic research, immune system, non-hodgkin lymphoma, blood cancer, rituximab, cancer treatment

row.field_short_title: Targeted Treatments for a Type of Pancreatic Cancer
row.field_page_description: Thanks to discovering the anticancer effects of mTOR inhibitors, cancer treatment for pNet, a rare type of pancreatic cancer, were revolutionized. Through clinical trials, NCI continues to investigate the life-saving potential of mTOR inhibitors.

row.title: The NCI Outstanding Investigator Award (R35)

row.title: RAS Cell Lines
row.field_page_description: Cell lines expressing mutant RAS genes are essential tools for finding ways to intervene in RAS cancers. Learn about the work of NCI RAS Initiative scientists to engineer and characterize these cell lines, creating a reliable resource.

row.title: Understanding Cervical Changes: Next Steps After an Abnormal Screening Test
row.field_page_description: Explains abnormal Pap test, HPV test, and Pap/HPV cotest results. Treatment and follow-up care for abnormal cervical cancer screening results including ASC-US, AGC, LSIL, ASC-H, HSIL, AIS. Learn about colposcopy, types of biopsies, CIN, and HPV vaccine.
row.field_feature_card_description: Explains HPV Infection; cervical cancer screening tests including Pap test, HPV test, and Pap/HPV cotesting; new cervical cancer screening guidelines; possible Pap test results and Pap/HPV cotest results; follow-up testing; treatment; and HPV vaccination.
row.field_list_description: Learn what test results mean if a recent Pap test showed cell changes in the cervix or an HPV test was positive, including that not all cervical changes mean cancer; find out the importance of follow-up care and treatment for abnormal results.
row.field_browser_title: Understanding Cervical Changes: A Health Guide for Women

row.title: The ALCHEMIST Lung Cancer Trials
row.field_page_description: A collection of material about the ALCHEMIST lung cancer trials that will examine tumor tissue from patients with certain types of early-stage, completely resected non-small cell lung cancer for gene mutations in the EGFR and ALK genes, and assign patients with these gene mutations to treatment trials testing post-surgical use of drugs targeted against these mutations.
row.field_feature_card_description: These clinical trials are exploring whether targeted therapy can prevent the recurrence of certain subtypes of early-stage lung cancer.
row.field_list_description: A collection of material about the ALCHEMIST lung cancer trials that will examine tumor tissue from patients with certain types of early-stage, completely resected non-small cell lung cancer for gene mutations in the EGFR and ALK genes, and assign patients with these gene mutations to treatment trials testing post-surgical use of drugs targeted against these mutations.
row.meta_keywords: NSCLC, lung, ALK, EGFR, crizotinib, erlotinib

row.title: Targeted Therapy to Treat Cancer
row.field_page_description: Targeted therapy is a type of cancer treatment that targets the changes in cancer cells that help them grow, divide, and spread. Learn how targeted therapy works against cancer and about side effects that may occur.
row.field_feature_card_description: Targeted therapy is a type of cancer treatment that targets the changes in cancer cells that help them grow, divide, and spread. Learn how targeted therapy works against cancer and about side effects that may occur.
row.field_list_description: Targeted therapy is a type of cancer treatment that targets the changes in cancer cells that help them grow, divide, and spread. Learn how targeted therapy works against cancer and about common side effects that may occur.

row.title: RAS Drug Discovery
row.field_page_description: The RAS Drug Discovery group aims to develop assays that will reveal aspects of RAS biology upon which cancer cells depend. Successful assay formats are made available for high-throughput screening programs to yield potentially effective drug compounds.
row.field_feature_card_description: This group has developed and validated in vitro and in vivo assays suitable for screening large libraries of candidate drug compounds.
row.field_list_description: This group has developed and validated in vitro and in vivo assays suitable for screening large libraries of candidate drug compounds.

row.title: RAS Image-Based Screens
row.field_page_description: This laboratory develops screens based on live cell imaging of labeled RAS molecules.
row.field_feature_card_description: This laboratory develops screens based on live cell imaging of labeled RAS molecules.
row.field_list_description: This laboratory develops screens based on live cell imaging of labeled RAS molecules.

row.title: RAS Informatics
row.field_page_description: The RAS Informatics lab group develops tools to track and analyze “big data” from the RAS Initiative, as well as analyzes data from external projects. By integrating internal and external data, this group helps improve understanding of RAS-driven cancers.
row.field_feature_card_description: This lab group develops tools to track and analyze “big data” from the RAS Initiative and the larger RAS community.
row.field_list_description: This lab group develops tools to track and analyze “big data” from the RAS Initiative and the larger RAS community.

row.title: RAS Reagents
row.field_page_description: The RAS Reagents group prepares proteins, DNAs, and cell lines, all of which are required to attack cancers caused by mutant RAS.
row.field_feature_card_description: Attacking cancers caused by mutant RAS requires proteins, DNAs, and cell lines prepared by this group.
row.field_list_description: Attacking cancers caused by mutant RAS requires proteins, DNAs, and cell lines prepared by this group.

row.title: RAS Structural Biology
row.field_page_description: The RAS Structural Biology group determines the structures of RAS proteins, alone and in complex with important effectors.
row.field_feature_card_description: This group aims to provide structural insights into oncogenic mutants of RAS, RAS-effector, and RAS-interactor complexes.
row.field_list_description: This group aims to provide structural insights into oncogenic mutants of RAS, RAS-effector, and RAS-interactor complexes.

row.title: Managing Costs and Medical Information
row.field_page_description: People with cancer may face major financial challenges and need help dealing with the high costs of care. Cancer treatment can be very expensive, even when you have insurance. Learn ways to manage medical information, paperwork, bills, and other records.

row.title: Cancer Cell Biology Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI's Division of Cancer Biology research portfolio, this research defines the biological basis for the differences between normal cells and cancer cells.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI supports research into the biology of cancer, with an emphasis on processes and molecular targets that might lead to better therapies.
row.field_list_description: A research area that defines the biological basis for the differences between normal cells and cancer cells, with a major emphasis on studies that reveal processes and molecular targets where there is potential for therapeutic or preventive intervention.

row.title: Cancer Immunology, Hematology, and Etiology Research
row.field_short_title: Cancer Immunology, Hematology, and Etiology Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI’s Division of Cancer Biology’s research portfolio, studies supported include the characterization of basic mechanisms relevant to anti-tumor immune responses and hematologic malignancies.
row.field_feature_card_description: Studies supported include the characterization of basic mechanisms relevant to anti-tumor immune responses and hematologic malignancies.
row.field_list_description: Part of NCI’s Division of Cancer Biology’s research portfolio, studies supported include the characterization of basic mechanisms relevant to anti-tumor immune responses and hematologic malignancies.

row.field_card_title: Cancer Immunology, Hematology, and Etiology Research

row.title: DNA and Chromosome Aberrations Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI's Division of Cancer Biology's research portfolio, this research area is focused on making clear the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms of tumorigenesis and mechanisms of chemical and physical carcinogenesis.
row.field_feature_card_description: Examines cancer genetics and epigenetics, including regulation of gene expression, mechanisms of DNA damage/repair, genomic instability, and related molecular, cytogenetic, and chromosomal effects during induction and progression to malignancy.
row.field_list_description: Examines cancer genetics and epigenetics, including regulation of gene expression, mechanisms of DNA damage/repair, genomic instability, and related molecular, cytogenetic, and chromosomal effects during induction and progression to malignancy.

row.title: Structural Biology and Molecular Applications Research
row.field_short_title: Structural Biology and Molecular Applications Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI's Division of Cancer Biology's research portfolio, research and development in this area focuses on enabling technologies, models, and methodologies to support basic and applied cancer research.
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer research and development in this area focuses on enabling technologies, models, and methodologies to support basic and applied cancer research.
row.field_list_description: Cancer research and discovery in this area focuses on technology development and molecular applications, biophysical biology, and computational/mathematical methods and bioinformatics development.

row.title: Tumor Biology and Microenvironment Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI's Division of Cancer Biology's research portfolio, research in this area seeks to understand the role of tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment (TME) in driving cancer initiation, progression, maintenance and recurrence.
row.field_feature_card_description: Research in this area seeks to understand the role of tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment (TME) in driving cancer initiation, progression, maintenance and recurrence.
row.field_list_description: Research in this area seeks to understand the role of tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment in driving cancer processes. Understanding the cellular, molecular, and biochemical interactions of tumors within their microenvironment is essential to improving cancer diagnosis and treatment.

row.title: Intensify Research on the Major Drivers of Childhood Cancers
row.field_page_description: Fusion oncoproteins can lead to the development of childhood cancers. This Cancer Moonshot initiative aims to improve our understanding of these proteins and develop inhibitors that target them.

row.field_list_description: Improve our understanding of fusion oncoproteins in pediatric cancer and use new preclinical models to develop inhibitors that target them.

row.title: Analyze Patient Data and Biospecimens from Past Clinical Trials to Predict Future Patient Outcomes
row.field_short_title: Mine Past Patient Data to Predict Future Patient Outcomes
row.field_page_description: Tumor samples and other biospecimens can be analyzed retrospectively to develop hypotheses about which tumor features can help predict clinical benefit. Ideally, this information can be used to improve treatment and outcomes for cancer patients.
row.field_feature_card_description: A Cancer Moonshot initiative created to retrospectively analyze patient tumor samples to improve patient outcomes.
row.field_list_description: Predict response to standard treatments through retrospective analysis of patient specimens.

row.title: Develop Ways to Overcome Cancer’s Resistance to Therapy
row.field_page_description: Cancer cells can develop resistance to drugs that were previously effective. This Cancer Moonshot initiative aims to increase understanding of how this resistance develops, and to use biomarkers to predict who will develop it, and ways to counteract it to improve patient care and survival.
row.field_feature_card_description: This Cancer Moonshot initiative aims to improve our understanding of drug resistance in cancer and how to overcome it.
row.field_list_description: Identify therapeutic targets to overcome drug resistance through studies that determine the mechanisms that lead cancer cells to become resistant to previously effective treatments.
row.field_browser_title: Overcoming Drug Resistance - Cancer Moonshot Recommendation

row.title: Cetuximab Combined with Oxaliplatin-Based Chemotherapy May Not Be Effective First-Line Treatment for Metastatic Colorectal Cancer
row.field_short_title: Cetuximab Plus Oxaliplatin May Not Be Effective Primary Treatment for Metastatic Colorectal Cancer
row.field_page_description: In a randomized phase III trial, the addition of the targeted therapy cetuximab to oxaliplatin and fluoropyrimidine chemotherapy did not prolong survival or time to disease progression of patients with advanced colorectal cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: In a randomized phase III trial, the addition of the targeted therapy cetuximab to oxaliplatin and fluoropyrimidine chemotherapy did not prolong survival or time to disease progression of patients with advanced colorectal cancer.
row.field_list_description: In a randomized phase III trial, the addition of the targeted therapy cetuximab to oxaliplatin and fluoropyrimidine chemotherapy did not prolong survival or time to disease progression of patients with advanced colorectal cancer. The results were published on June 5, 2011 in The Lancet.
row.field_browser_title: Cetuximab Plus Oxaliplatin May Not Be Effective Primary Treatment for Metastatic Colorectal Cancer
row.field_card_title: Cetuximab Plus Oxaliplatin May Not Be Effective Primary Treatment for Metastatic Colorectal Cancer
row.meta_keywords: colorectal, colon, rectal, metastasis, COIN, Maughan, cetuximab, oxaliplatin, KRAS, EGFR

row.title: Chemotherapy Less Toxic to the Heart May Be Option for Some Women with HER2-Positive Breast Cancer
row.field_short_title: Chemotherapy Less Toxic to the Heart May Be Option for Some Women with HER2-Positive Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: A nonanthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen combined with the targeted therapy trastuzumab may be an option for some women with HER2-positive breast cancer, according to results from the BCIRG-006 trial.
row.field_feature_card_description: A nonanthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen combined with the targeted therapy trastuzumab may be an option for some women with HER2-positive breast cancer, according to results from the BCIRG-006 trial.
row.field_list_description: A nonanthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen combined with the targeted therapy trastuzumab may be an option for some women with HER2-positive breast cancer, according to results from the Breast Cancer International Research Group 006 (BCIRG-006) trial reported October 6, 2011, in the New England Journal of Medicine.

row.title: Long-Term Data from 20 Trials Confirm Tamoxifen’s Long-Lasting Benefit
row.field_short_title: Long-Term Data from 20 Trials Confirm Tamoxifen's Long-Lasting Benefit
row.field_page_description: Women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer who received about 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen had a lower risk of recurrence in the 15 years after treatment than women who did not receive tamoxifen.
row.field_feature_card_description: Women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer who received about 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen had a lower risk of recurrence in the 15 years after treatment than women who did not receive tamoxifen.
row.field_list_description: In an analysis of data from participants in 20 clinical trials, women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer who received about 5 years of adjuvant treatment with tamoxifen had a lower risk of recurrence in the 15 years after starting treatment than women who did not receive tamoxifen.
row.field_browser_title: Long-Term Data from 20 Trials Confirm Tamoxifen's Long-Lasting Benefit
row.field_card_title: Long-Term Data from 20 Trials Confirm Tamoxifen's Long-Lasting Benefit
row.meta_keywords: breast, tamoxifen, estrogen, estrogen receptor, ER positive, EBCTCG

row.title: Study Confirms Letrozole Prevents More Breast Cancer Recurrences than Tamoxifen
row.field_short_title: Study Confirms Letrozole Prevents More Breast Cancer Recurrences than Tamoxifen
row.field_page_description: After a median of 8 years of follow-up, women with estrogen-receptor positive breast cancer who received 5 years of letrozole were less likely to have their cancer recur or to die during follow-up than women who received 5 years of tamoxifen.
row.field_feature_card_description: After a median of 8 years of follow-up, women with estrogen-receptor positive breast cancer who received 5 years of letrozole were less likely to have their cancer recur or to die during follow-up than women who received 5 years of tamoxifen.
row.field_list_description: After a median of 8 years of follow-up from a large randomized trial, women with estrogen-receptor positive breast cancer who received 5 years of treatment with letrozole were less likely to have their cancer recur or to die during follow-up than women who had 5 years of treatment with tamoxifen.
row.field_browser_title: Study Confirms Letrozole Prevents More Breast Cancer Recurrences than Tamoxifen
row.field_card_title: Study Confirms Letrozole Prevents More Breast Cancer Recurrences than Tamoxifen
row.meta_keywords: breast, BIG 1-98, letrozole, tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitor, aromatase, Bulletin

row.title: Study Suggests Smaller Melanoma Excision Margins May Be Option for Some Patients
row.field_short_title: Study Suggests Smaller Melanoma Excision Margins May Be Option for Some Patients
row.field_page_description: A randomized controlled trial of patients with stage IIA–C cutaneous melanoma thicker than 2-mm found that a 2-cm surgical resection margin is sufficient and is as safe for patients as a 4-cm margin.
row.field_feature_card_description: A randomized controlled trial of patients with stage IIA–C cutaneous melanoma thicker than 2-mm found that a 2-cm surgical resection margin is sufficient and is as safe for patients as a 4-cm margin.
row.field_list_description: A randomized controlled trial of patients with stage IIA–C cutaneous melanoma thicker than 2-mm found that a 2-cm surgical resection margin is sufficient and is as safe for patients as a 4-cm margin in terms of overall survival, according to a report published online October 21 in The Lancet.

row.title: Exemestane Following Tamoxifen Reduces Breast Cancer Recurrences and Prolongs Survival
row.field_short_title: Exemestane Following Tamoxifen Reduces Breast Cancer Recurrences and Prolongs Survival
row.field_page_description: Postmenopausal women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer had delayed disease recurrence and longer survival after taking 2-3 years of tamoxifen followed by exemestane for a total of 5 years compared to taking tamoxifen for 5 years.
row.field_feature_card_description: Postmenopausal women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer had delayed disease recurrence and longer survival after taking 2-3 years of tamoxifen followed by exemestane for a total of 5 years compared to taking tamoxifen for 5 years.
row.field_list_description: Long-term follow-up data from a large international phase III trial shows that postmenopausal women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer who received 2 to 3 years of tamoxifen and then switched to the drug exemestane (Aromasin®) for a total of 5 years of adjuvant hormone therapy experienced a delay in disease recurrence and a survival advantage, compared with women who took tamoxifen for 5 years.

row.field_page_description: A summary of results from a large randomized clinical trial that shows a new human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine effectively prevented infection and disease caused by seven HPV types that cause cancer and two HPV types that cause genital warts.
row.field_feature_card_description: In a large randomized clinical trial, a new human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine effectively prevented infection and disease caused by seven HPV types that cause cancer and two HPV types that cause genital warts.
row.field_list_description: In a large randomized clinical trial, a new human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine effectively prevented infection and disease caused by nine HPV types, including seven types that cause cervical and other cancers—five of which were not covered by the previously available HPV vaccines—and two types that cause genital warts.

row.title: Interagency Oncology Task Force Fellowship
row.field_page_description: In collaboration with FDA, these fellowships train scientists in research and research-related regulatory review, policies, and regulations to develop a skill set that bridges the two disparate processes.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI and FDA train scientists in research and regulatory review.
row.field_list_description: In collaboration with FDA, these fellowships train scientists in research and research-related regulatory review, policies, and regulations to develop a skill set that bridges the two disparate processes.
row.intro:
The Interagency Oncology Task Force Fellowship program trains scientists in research and research-related regulatory review, policies, and regulations to develop a skill set that bridges the two disparate processes. Fellows learn to build awareness of regulatory requirements into the early stages of the medical product development process and will develop strategies to improve planning throughout research and regulatory review.

The fellowship is offered as a partnership of the National Cancer Institute (NCI), National Institutes of Health (NIH), and U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the U.S. Department Health and Human Services (HHS).

*Selection of fellows will be dependent upon the availabilty of funds.
row.meta_keywords: NCI and FDA collaborate to train scientists in research and research-related regulatory review and policies. Learn more about this cancer training program.
